read.title: üìñ Hobbies That Connect Us
read.passage:
Around the world, children share many similar hobbies even though they live in different countries.

In Oman, Ahmed loves going camping with his family in Jebel Akhdar. They bring tents, cook traditional food, and enjoy the cool mountain air.

In Japan, Yuki practices karate three times a week. She also enjoys calligraphy, a traditional art of beautiful writing.

In Brazil, Carlos plays football every day after school. His dream is to become a professional player.

In the UK, Emma goes to drama club where she acts in school plays. She also loves cycling in the park with her friends.

Even though their hobbies are different, all four children learn important skills: teamwork, creativity, and staying healthy. Hobbies connect us all, no matter where we live!

read.title: üìñ Planning the Perfect Weekend
read.passage:
It's Friday afternoon in Muscat. Four friends are planning their weekend.

"Let's go to the beach!" says Sara excitedly.

"Hmm, it might be too hot," replies Ahmed. "How about going to the mall instead?"

"Good idea!" says Fatima. "We can watch a movie and get ice cream."

"Wait," interrupts Khalid. "Why don't we go hiking in Jebel Akhdar? The weather is perfect for it."

The friends think for a moment.

"That sounds amazing, but it's far," says Sara. "Shall we go next weekend instead? This weekend we can go to the mall."

"Deal!" everyone agrees.

By making suggestions and listening to each other, the friends created a plan that made everyone happy. Sometimes the best plans come from working together!

read.passage:
My name is Khalid and I live in Muscat. Technology is everywhere in my house!

In the morning, my dad's smartwatch wakes him up. It also shows his messages and counts his steps.

My mom uses her smartphone to order groceries online. The delivery arrives in just one hour!

I use my laptop for school. It helps me write reports and watch educational videos. My little sister has a tablet that teaches her Arabic and English through fun games.

In the kitchen, we have a microwave that heats food quickly. My mom also uses a vacuum cleaner to clean the floors every day.

At night, we all watch TV together. Our smart TV connects to the internet, so we can watch Omani shows and documentaries.

Technology makes our life easier, faster, and more fun. I can't imagine living without it!

read.title: üìñ Sara's Smart Choice
read.passage:
Sara is 11 years old and loves playing online games. One day, while playing her favorite game, someone sent her a message.

"Hi Sara! I'm your friend Ahmed. Can you tell me your phone number?"

Sara felt confused. She didn't remember having a friend named Ahmed in the game.

She thought: "Should I answer? This person might be a stranger."

Sara remembered her teacher's lesson about internet safety. Her teacher always said: "You shouldn't share personal information with people you don't know online."

Sara closed the chat and told her mom about the message. Her mom was proud of her.

"You made a very smart choice, Sara," her mom said. "You can't trust everyone online. Always tell an adult if something feels wrong."

From that day, Sara always thought carefully before chatting with anyone online. She knew that being safe was more important than being polite to strangers.

Technology makes learning so much more interesting and interactive!

read.title: üìñ Ahmed's Dream Invention
read.passage:
Ahmed is a 12-year-old student from Salalah who loves inventing things.

Last week, his teacher asked the class: "What invention would make the world better?"

Ahmed thought carefully. In the past, people couldn't clean beaches easily. They had to pick up trash by hand, which took hours.

"I want to invent a solar-powered robot that collects plastic from beaches!" Ahmed announced.

His teacher smiled. "That's wonderful! In the past, we couldn't use solar power for robots, but now we can!"

Ahmed drew his invention. The robot had:
‚úì Solar panels for clean energy
‚úì Sensors to detect plastic
‚úì A container to store the trash

"When I grow up, I want to study engineering at Sultan Qaboos University," Ahmed said. "Technology can help protect Oman's beautiful coastline!"

His classmates loved the idea. Some students couldn't draw robots well, but they all had to try. Everyone felt excited about using technology for a better world.

read.title: üìñ Exploring Muscat
read.passage:
Sara and her family are exploring Muscat this weekend.

On Friday morning, they visit the Sultan Qaboos Grand Mosque. Sara loves it because it is peaceful and beautiful. The mosque has a big garden and a huge prayer hall with a magnificent chandelier.

"I like this place," Sara tells her father. "It has amazing architecture!"

On Saturday, they go to Nizwa Fort, an old castle in the mountains. Her brother Ahmed enjoys learning about Omani history. The fort has tall towers and thick walls.

"Do you like castles?" Ahmed asks.

"Yes, I do!" Sara replies. "They tell us stories about the past."

In the evening, they walk across Mutrah Corniche and see the beautiful bridge connecting different parts of the city. Muscat has many wonderful places!

"Which place is your favorite?" their mother asks.

Sara thinks for a moment. "I love them all, but the Grand Mosque is the most beautiful!"

read.title: üìñ Lost in the Mall
read.passage:
Ahmed and his little sister Maryam are at Muscat Grand Mall.

Maryam wants to find the toy shop, but they don't know where it is. Ahmed sees an information board near the entrance.

"Let's ask someone," Maryam suggests.

They walk along the corridor and find a helpful security guard.

"Excuse me, where is the toy shop?" Ahmed asks politely.

The guard smiles. "It's easy! Go straight ahead along this corridor. Then take the escalator to the second floor. The toy shop is next to the food court, on your left."

"Thank you!" they both say.

They follow the directions carefully. First, they walk along the corridor. The ceiling is very high and there are many shops on both sides. Then they see the escalator and go up.

On the second floor, they turn left and see the toy shop immediately!

"We found it!" Maryam says happily.

Ahmed is proud. "Now I know how to give directions in buildings!"

read.passage:
Fatima is walking near Muttrah Souq when a tourist stops her.

"Excuse me," says the tourist. "Can you tell me where the National Museum is, please?"

The tourist follows Fatima's directions carefully. She goes straight ahead, walks past the buildings, and turns right at the roundabout. Soon, she sees the blue sign and finds the museum easily.

Fatima feels proud. She helped someone in English! Now she knows how useful learning directions can be.

read.title: üìñ A Journey Through Time
read.passage:
Ahmed's grandfather is telling him a story about traveling to Nizwa when he was young.

"When I was your age," Grandfather says, "we were riding camels to visit Nizwa. The journey took three days! We were sleeping under the stars and cooking over a fire. It was slow, but it was beautiful."

Ahmed listens carefully. "That sounds amazing! But why didn't you use a car?"

Grandfather smiles. "There weren't many roads back then. People used to travel the old way. Camels were slower than cars, but they knew the desert well."

"Now it's so different!" Ahmed says excitedly. "Last week, we drove to Nizwa in just two hours. We visited the fort and the souq. It was fantastic!"

"Yes," Grandfather agrees. "Modern travel is faster and more comfortable. But I think in the future, it will be even more amazing. Maybe you will fly there in a few minutes!"

Ahmed imagines flying cars zooming over the mountains. "I wonder what Nizwa will look like in 100 years," he says.

"The old fort will still be there," Grandfather says wisely. "Some things don't change. But the ways we explore them do!"

Ahmed feels grateful. He loves learning about the past and dreaming about the future.

Fatima raises her hand. "We use apps on our phones. Is that software?"

"Exactly!" Dr. Ahmed smiles. "Apps are software for smartphones. Your phone is a device with many functions."

He shows them medical machines. "In Muscat's modern hospitals, doctors use advanced devices. These machines help diagnose illnesses and save lives."

Ali asks, "Can robots do homework for us?"

Fatima thinks about all the devices around her: smartphones, washing machines, computers, robots. Technology is everywhere, making life easier!

read.title: üìñ The Story of the Falaj
read.passage:
Ahmed is doing a school project about Omani inventions. His grandfather is helping him.

"Let me tell you about the falaj," Grandfather says. "Our ancestors invented this system over 1,500 years ago."

"What did it do?" Ahmed asks.

"The falaj brought water from the mountains to farms and villages," Grandfather explains. "Engineers built underground channels. They dug tunnels and calculated the slope perfectly. Water flowed by gravity‚Äîno pumps needed!"

Ahmed is amazed. "That's like ancient technology!"

"Yes!" Grandfather smiles. "People all over the world invented things to solve problems. Thomas Edison invented the light bulb. The Wright Brothers built the first airplane. But our ancestors created the falaj to survive in the desert."

"Is it still used today?" Ahmed asks.

Grandfather nods. "Some villages still use traditional falaj systems. UNESCO recognized them as World Heritage. Modern engineers study how our ancestors designed them so well."

Ahmed writes in his notebook: 'Omani engineers invented the falaj. They built it without modern tools. It worked for over a thousand years.'

"I'm proud of our history," Ahmed says.

"You should be," Grandfather replies. "Innovation isn't just about new gadgets. It's about solving problems creatively‚Äîthen and now."

read.title: üìñ Maryam Learns About Online Safety
read.passage:
Maryam got a new tablet for her birthday. She's excited to use it!

Her mother sits with her. "Before you start, we must talk about safety," she says.

"Okay, Mama," Maryam agrees.

"First, you must keep your password secret," Mother explains. "Don't share it with anyone except me and your father."

"Not even my best friend?" Maryam asks.

"Not even your best friend," Mother confirms. "And you mustn't share personal information online. That means our address, phone number, or school name."

Maryam nods. "I understand."

"You have to ask permission before downloading new apps," Mother continues. "And you don't have to answer messages from people you don't know. Just ignore them."

"What if someone is mean to me online?" Maryam asks.

"You must tell me immediately," Mother says firmly. "Cyberbullying is serious. Also, you mustn't be mean to others online either. Always be kind."

Mother shows Maryam the privacy settings. "Keep your account private. Only accept friend requests from real friends."

Finally, Mother talks about screen time. "You don't have to be online all the time. Take breaks. Play outside. Read books. Balance is important."

Maryam creates her safety rules list:
‚Ä¢ Must keep password secret
‚Ä¢ Mustn't share personal info
‚Ä¢ Must tell parents about problems
‚Ä¢ Don't have to respond to strangers

"Now you're ready!" Mother smiles. "Enjoy your tablet safely!"

read.title: üìñ Ahmed's Dream: Technology Helping Oman
read.passage:
Ahmed is writing an essay for school about "Technology for a Better Oman."

He begins: "In the future, technology will make Oman even better. I have many ideas!"

**Healthcare:**
"Robots will help doctors at Royal Hospital Muscat," Ahmed writes. "They will perform surgeries more precisely. Apps will remind elderly people to take their medicine. Air ambulances will reach remote villages faster."

**Education:**
"Technology will improve learning," he continues. "Students in mountain villages will attend online classes. Virtual reality will let us visit historical sites without leaving school. AI tutors will help students who need extra support. But teachers won't be replaced‚Äîthey will always be important!"

**Environment:**
"Solar panels will power more homes and schools," Ahmed predicts. "Electric cars will reduce pollution in Muscat. Smart systems will save water in the desert. Oman will become a leader in renewable energy."

**Daily Life:**
"Robots will help farmers plant dates and harvest crops," he imagines. "Delivery drones will bring medicine to remote areas. Smart traffic systems will reduce traffic jams."

His teacher reads the essay and smiles. "Excellent work, Ahmed! But remember‚Äîtechnology won't solve everything alone. We need creative, kind people like you to use it wisely."

Ahmed nods. "I will study hard. Maybe I'll become an engineer and help make these ideas real!"

"I believe you will," his teacher says proudly.
